Scheme 1 Hollow hierarchical zinc cobalt sulfides derived from bimetallic-organic-framework as a non-precious electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction reaction Dongwook Lim 1 Kyeongseok Min 1 Minji Hwang Hyung Chul Ham Geon-Joong Kim Sung-Hyeon Baeck ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Education and Research Center for Smart Energy Materials and Process, Inha University, 100 Inha-ro, Incheon 22212, Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Education and Research Center for Smart Energy Materials and Process Inha University 100 Inha-ro Incheon 22212 Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Education and Research Center for Smart Energy Materials and Process, Inha University, 100 Inha-ro, Incheon 22212, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Herein, pyrolysis strategy assisted by a dual-metal-ZIF is developed to synthesize porous zinc cobalt sulfide supported on nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon (Zn-Co-S@NSC). A dodecahedral ZIF architecture is first constructed with two metal sources, followed by a pyrolysis process with thiourea to obtain hollow composite materials consisting of Zn-Co sulfide uniformly dispersed on nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon. Benefitting from the distinctive structure and synergistic effect of the binary metal system, the as-prepared Zn-Co-S@NSC displays excellent electrocatalytic performance on ORR in alkaline condition. The superior performances, which are evaluated in terms of onset-potential (0.955 V vs. RHE) and half-wave potential (0.831 V vs. RHE), are comparable to the conventional Pt/C catalyst. In addition, Zn-Co-S@NSC exhibits remarkable electrochemical durability and exceptional methanol tolerance compared to the commercial Pt/C. The DFT calculations further demonstrate that the binary metal system can promote electrocatalytic activity by optimizing the reaction free energy for intermediates of ORR. Graphical abstract Zn-Co-S@NSC was synthesized using pyrolysis strategy assisted by a dual-metal-ZIF. The synergistic effect of binary metal system led to outstanding ORR performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks Metal sulfide Electrocatalyst Oxygen reduction reaction Density functional theory 1 Introduction Over the past century, the excessive use of fossil fuels owing to industrial developments and the increasing demand for energy has intensified the environmental crisis [1,2]. It is important to explore other sustainable energy storage and conversion systems including metal–air batteries and fuel cells to address this issue [3,4]. With the increasing interest in the electrochemical process, electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) have become the key for their energy efficiency owing to the sluggish kinetics of the four-electron involved pathways [5–7]. Platinum and its alloys are well established as ultra-high active electrocatalysts for ORR [8,9]. However, the severe drawbacks of these Pt-based catalysts, such as high expense, low stability, and scarcity have been hindering the widespread application and large-scale commercialization of fuel cells [10–12]. Hence, significant research efforts have been devoted to the development of non-precious ORR catalysts that are inexpensive, highly durable, and earth-abundant [13–16]. In recent years, metal organic frameworks (MOFs), consisting of metal cations coordinated to rigid organic ligands, have gained substantial interest as potential candidates for electrochemical applications. This is because of their intrinsic properties such as high porosity, ordered crystalline structure, and versatile functionalities [17,18]. In particular, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), a subclass of MOFs comprising metal ions and imidazolate linkers, have emerged as novel self-sacrificed templates for fabricating uniformly dispersed metal sulfide/oxide nanoparticles as non-precious metal electrocatalysts, through thermal decomposition under optimized conditions [19–21]. The ZIF-derived porous materials with metal sulfide or oxide nanoparticles homogeneously distributed on a heteroatom-doped carbon matrix possess large internal surface area and rich edge active sites, which can improve the electrochemical performance by accelerating the kinetics and facilitating the mass transfer of reactants to the pores [22,23]. For example, Cao and co-workers [24] prepared ZnO on 3D graphene network by thermal decomposition of ZIF-8, for photocatalysis and a lithium-ion battery (LIB). The Han group [25] synthesized a cobalt sulfide nanosheet array on Ni foam derived from a 2D Co-based leaf-like ZIF, which exhibited exceptional electrochemical performance as an electrode material for a supercapacitor. Among the various ZIF-derived materials, transition metal-based sulfides have received tremendous attention owing to their good cost-effectiveness, natural abundance, and high electrochemical performance [26,27]. In particular, bi-metallic sulfides are considered as potential materials for ORR because of their higher redox reactivity than that of monometallic sulfides and enhanced charge transfer capability between different metal cations [28,29]. Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, research on the synthesis of bi-metallic sulfide on heteroatom-codoped carbon composites derived from ZIF, which exhibit high ORR activities, is rarely reported. In addition, the practical applications of bi-metallic sulfides continue to be adversely affected by their low conductivity and low structural stability, which result in ineffective activity compared to that of precious metal catalysts [30,31]. Therefore, bi-metallic sulfide combined with conductive carbon supports such as graphene oxide, carbon fiber, and heteroatom-doped carbon is one of the widely adopted strategies to improve electrochemical performance [32–35]. In this study, we successfully synthesized zinc-cobalt sulfides uniformly dispersed on nitrogen and sulfur co-doped porous carbon hybrid composites (Zn-Co-S@NSC), by sulfurizing bi-metallic Zn-Co-ZIF with thiourea under an inert atmosphere. The as-synthesized Zn-Co-S@NSC maintained the inherent dodecahedral shape of ZIF even after the thermal treatment. And, it has a large specific surface area, which provides abundant electrocatalytic active sites and effective mass transfer for ORR. As anticipated, the Zn-Co-S@NSC catalyst displayed remarkable ORR onset-potential (0.955 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) and half-wave potential (0.831 V vs. RHE), which are comparable to those of commercial Pt/C catalyst in alkaline solution. Moreover, a long-term stability (for 100 h) was observed without significant activity degradation under galvanostatic measurement. The theoretical calculation further demonstrates that the Zn-Co-S@NSC exhibits an optimized free energy for the potential‐determining step (PDS) of the adsorbed intermediates, which effectively increase the electrochemical activity for ORRs. These observations indicate that the bi-metallic sulfides on N, S co-doped porous carbon can be a potential alternative as non-noble electrocatalysts for ORRs in advanced energy storage and conversion technologies. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Zn-Co-ZIF The bi-metallic Zn-Co-ZIF nanocrystals were synthesized with certain modification to a previously reported procedure [36]. Typically, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (892.5 mg, 3 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (291.0 mg, 1 mmol) were dissolved in methanol (30 mL). In addition, 2-methylimidazole (2.0 g, 24 mmol) was dispersed in methanol (20 mL), separately. Then, the two solutions were mixed by vigorously stirring for 1 h and aged at room temperature for 24 h. Finally, the violet precipitates were centrifuged at 8000 rpm for several times (10 min each time) using methanol, and then dried at 50 °C overnight. For comparison, Zn-ZIF and Co-ZIF were also synthesized using a similar procedure, albeit in the absence of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, respectively. 2.2 Synthesis of Zn-Co-S@NSC As-prepared ZIFs were transformed into metal sulfide on N, S doped carbon through simultaneous sulfurization and carbonization. A Zn-Co-ZIF (0.2 g) was weighed into an alumina boat and placed to the downstream of a tube furnace. Another alumina boat loaded with thiourea (1.2 g) was transferred to the inlet side of the tube furnace. Then, they were pyrolyzed at 700 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under argon gas flow. After natural cooling, the black product was removed and denoted as Zn-Co-S@NSC. For comparison, Zn-ZIF and Co-ZIF were heat-treated under identical conditions and denoted as Zn-S@NSC and Co-S@NSC, respectively. 2.3 Physical characterization of Zn-Co-S@NSC The crystal structure and phase analysis of the nanoparticles were examined using X-ray diffraction (XRD; RIGAKU, D/MAX 2200 V/PC) with a Cu Kα (λ = 0.154 nm) radiation. The surface morphology of the prepared catalysts was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Hitachi, S-4300SE) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL, JEM2100F). The specific surface area and pore size of samples were elaborately investigated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis and the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020), respectively. The chemical valence states of the materials were scrutinized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo Scientific, ESCA 2000) measurements using monochromated Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV). The elemental content was investigated by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES; PerkinElmer, Optima 7300DV). Elemental analysis of C, N, and S was carried out by using a EA1112 CHNOS elemental analyzer. 2.4 Electrochemical characterization of Zn-Co-S@NSC All the electrochemical tests were carried out using a standard three-electrode system. The working, counter, and reference electrodes were a glassy carbon (GC) rotating disk electrode (RDE, 3 mm in diameter) with active substance, a graphite plate, and Hg/HgO electrodes, respectively. To prepare the working electrode, the RDE was polished using alumina slurry on felt polishing pads, followed by ultrasonication with milli-Q water. To prepare the GC electrode (GCE), the catalyst (2 mg) was added in a mixed solution containing isopropyl alcohol (100 μL), DI water (384 μL), and 5 wt.% Nafion solution (16 μL). After the solution was sonicated for several minutes, the homogeneous catalytic ink (5 μL) was loaded onto the GC electrode. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) were conducted to measure the electrochemical performance of the as-prepared electrodes in 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution at room temperature at scan rates of 100 mV s−1 and 5 mV s−1 for CV and LSV, respectively, with a potentiostat (Princeton Applied Research, VSP). All the measured potential values were converted with respect to RHE using the following equation: (1) E R H E = E H g / H g O + 0.0592 × p H + E H g / H g O 0 The Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equations Eqs. (2) and ((3)) are used for calculation of the transferred electron numbers (n) for reactions. (2) 1 J = 1 J K + 1 J D (3) J D = 0.62 nF D 2 / 3 v − 1 / 6 ω 1 / 2 C O 2 where J, JK, and JD are the measured, kinetic, and diffusion limiting current density, respectively; n is the electron transfer number; F is the Faraday constant (96,485 C mol−1); D is the diffusion coefficient of O2 in 0.1 M KOH (1.93 × 10−5 cm2 s−1); ν is the kinematic viscosity (1.09 × 10−2 cm2 s−1); ω is the angular rotation frequency ( ω = 2 π f / 60 ; f is the rotating speed of RDE); and C O 2 is the concentration of O2 in 0.1 M KOH (1.2 × 10−6 mol cm−3). The charge‐transfer resistance of the samples was investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in the frequency range 100 mHz to 100 kHz at 0.8 V vs. RHE. The stability of the samples was tested by the current-time chronoamperometric responses at 0.6 V (vs. RHE) for 100 h. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations The calculations of catalytic activity were performed on the basis of spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) as implemented in the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [37,38]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method using a plane wave basis set was applied to account for the interaction between atomic core and valence electrons. In order to properly describe the localized nature of the d electrons of Zn, the Hubbard-U terms (U-J = 6.0 eV) was added to DFT calculation [39]. A cutoff energy of 400 eV was used for the plane wave expansion of the kohn-sham orbitals [40]. For obtaining the equilibrium geometries and calculation of the total energies of the bulk ZnS and Zn0.76Co0.24S, we used (8 × 8 × 8) Monkhorst-Pack mesh of k-points to sample the Brillouin zone integration [41].. The equilibrium lattice constants for the bulk ZnS and Zn0.76Co0.24S were calculated to be a = 5.3775 Å and 5.3732 Å, respectively. For the ZnS (110) and Zn0.76Co0.24S (110) model surfaces (Fig. S1), we constructed a 2 × 2 slab consisting of eight atomic layers. Here, for the Zn0.76Co0.24S (110) slabs, we considered two different types of surface; that is, (1) CoZnS- terminated and (2) ZnS- terminated surfaces. We used an eight layered slab, where the bottom four layers were fixed to their bulk positions and the top four layers were allowed to fully relaxed using the conjugate gradient (CG) method with a convergence criterion of 0.02 eV/Å. Furthermore, in order to avoid interaction with the periodic images, a vacuum space equivalent to seven atomic layers was introduced. To calculate free energy and overpotential of the electrocatalytic ORR, we followed Nørskov's procedures [42]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of Zn-Co-S@NSC The procedure for synthesizing Zn-Co-S@NSC is depicted in Scheme 1. First, dodecahedron-shaped Zn-Co-ZIF particles were prepared by co-precipitation of Zn2+ and Co2+ cations with 2-methylimidazole at room temperature. The crystalline nature and morphology of the as-synthesized ZIFs were first examined by XRD and SEM. As shown in Fig. S2a, the characteristic peaks in the XRD patterns of Zn-Co-ZIF, Zn-ZIF, and Co-ZIF agree well with the results reported for ZIF-8 in the literature [8], indicating high crystallinity and phase purity of ZIF-8. The Zn-Co-ZIF was selected as the template for fabricating bi-metallic zinc-cobalt sulfides/heteroatom-doped carbon composites. The SEM images (Fig. S2b–d) reveal that all the prepared ZIF particles exhibit a rhombic dodecahedral shape with the smooth surface. The crystalline nature and unique morphology of the structure make them appropriate for gaining the desired electrocatalysts with abundant active sites and hierarchical structure for ORR. Subsequently, Zn-Co-S@NSC were synthesized by thermally treating Zn-Co-ZIF with thiourea powders placed in the upstream position of the furnace at 700 °C for 2 h under an argon atmosphere. During the pyrolysis stage, thiourea serves as the sulfur source for both the formation of bi-metallic sulfide and sulfur heteroatom doping in carbon matrix. The color of products after the heat treatment altered to black from purple owing to the conversion of ZIF materials to carbon-based materials. The XRD patterns of Zn-Co-S@NSC obtained by simultaneous sulfurization and carbonization process are shown in Fig. 1 a. Well-defined diffraction peaks were observed at 28.6°, 33.2°, 47.6°, 56.5°, 69.7°, and 77.0°, which are indexed to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (400), and (331) planes, respectively, of Zn0.76Co0.24S (JCPDS card no. 47–1656). The relatively small peaks at approximately 26.9°, 30.5°, and 51.8° are attributed to ZnS (JCPDS no. 10–0434). The low-magnification SEM image demonstrates that the as-derived Zn-Co-S@NSC particles preserve the rhombic dodecahedral shape and dimensions with the rough surface, as shown in Fig. 1b. As further clarified by TEM characterization, dodecahedral structures are evident after the thermal treatment, indicating high structural stability (Fig. 1c). It is noteworthy that the well-defined hollow structure is formed by the decomposition and sulfidation of Zn-Co-ZIF crystals. High-resolution (HR) TEM observation displays clear lattice fringes with an interplanar spacing of 0.161 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of Zn0.76Co0.24S (Fig. 1d). Moreover, elemental mapping using energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) of the selected area demonstrated that zinc, cobalt, sulfur, nitrogen, and carbon were distributed homogeneously over the entire surface of the Zn-Co-S@NSC catalyst, as shown in Fig. 1e. The homogeneous distribution of nitrogen indicates its incorporation in the carbon surface. In addition, sulfur is present on the Zn0.76Co0.24S surface and on the carbon matrix, indicating the presence of sulfur with zinc, cobalt, and the carbonized structure [43,44]. Raman spectroscopy was performed to acquire deeper structural information of carbon in the prepared samples, as shown in Fig. 2 a. All the samples clearly exhibit D band at approximately 1340 cm−1 and G band at approximately 1590 cm−1 in the Raman spectra, which indicate the distorted or defective graphitic carbon and ordered graphitic carbon, respectively [45]. This is because of the breathing modes of sp2 atoms in rings and the bond stretching of all the pairs of sp2 atoms in both rings and chains, respectively [22,46]. The values of ID/IG for Co-S@NSC, Zn-S@NSC, and Zn-Co-S@NSC are observed to be 0.992, 1.023, and 0.927, respectively. The lowest ID/IG ratio of Zn-Co-S@NSC indicates the highest degree of graphitic crystalline structure, which can be ascribed to the synergistic effect of binary metal in the formation of graphitic carbon [47,48]. This is considered to have enhanced the electrical conductivity and electron transfer efficiency, thereby playing a significant role in improving the ORR performance [49]. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the Zn-Co-S@NSC sample were characterized further by nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiments at 77 K. The nitrogen sorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distributions are shown in Fig. 2b,c. All the samples exhibited combined characteristics of type IV sorption isotherms (Figs. 2b and S5a,), indicating the presence of mesopores [50,51]. An apparent hysteresis loop is detected in the high relative pressure region (0.5 < P/P0 < 1), which indicates the presence of a mesoporous structure. The specific surface area and pore volume of Zn-Co-S@NSC are calculated to be 262.91 m2 g−1 and 0.265 cm3 g−1, respectively. As confirmed, the pore size distribution demonstrated that the Zn-Co-S@NSC is comprised mainly of mesopores (Fig. 2c). It is well-recognized that the specific surface area and pore structure are important to the highly efficient electrocatalyst for ORR. According to previously reported studies [52,53], the porous structure promote rapid transfer and diffusion for oxygen reduction-related species, which is likely to be exceptionally beneficial for the ORR activity. The chemical composition and oxidation states of the prepared samples were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements in Fig. 3 . The survey spectrum on Zn-Co-S@NSC catalyst in Fig. 3a indicated the simultaneous presence of Zn, Co, S, N, and C, with the atomic percentages as 6.52, 1.61, 13.50, 14.08, and 64.29%, respectively, which is summarized in Table S1. As shown in Fig. 3b, the two strong peaks centered at 1021.4 and 1044.6 eV in the Zn 2p region are attributed to the binding energies of Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 in Zn-Co-S@NSC, respectively, implying the presence of the Zn2+ [54]. The spectrum of Co 2p can be deconvoluted into two main spin–orbit coupling peaks of Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 in conjunction with the two shake-up satellite peaks located at 802.9 and 786.2 eV, respectively (denoted as Sat.). The two spin–orbit doublets at 796.6 and 780.6 eV correspond to the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 signals of Co2+. Meanwhile, those at 793.1 and 778.1 eV can be ascribed to the Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 signals of Co3+, indicating the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+ in the Zn-Co-S@NSC [55]. The high-resolution N 1 s spectrum indicates the presence of three types of nitrogen species, pyridinic N at 398.2 eV, pyrrolic N at 399.0 eV, and graphitic N at 400.4 eV (Fig. 3d) [56]. In particular, pyridinic N possesses a lone pair of electrons and donates an electron to the conjugated π-bond system, which can facilitate adsorption of oxygen molecules [57]. Graphitic N can lower the energy barriers for the electron transfer to attain a direct four-electron pathway for ORR [58]. As shown in Table S2, Zn-Co-S@NSC possesses the highest pyridinic N and graphitic N content among the prepared samples, which is beneficial to significantly boosting the electrocatalytic activity for ORR. In the S 2p spectrum (Fig. 3e), the major two peaks centered at 161.4 and 162.6 eV are assigned to the spin–orbit coupling in metal sulfide [33]. Meanwhile, the S 2p peaks at 163.7 and 165.1 eV are attributed to the presence of covalent C–S and C = S bonds in the as-synthesized sample [59]. This reveals the covalent insertion of sulfur into N-doped carbon [22]. The S dopant can modify the spin density distribution around the carbon matrix, thereby accelerating the reaction rate for ORR [60]. The successful N and S doping in the carbon matrix is further verified by high-resolution C 1 s spectrum (Fig. 3f). Here, the peaks located at 284.5 eV, 285.3 eV, 286.0 eV, 286.5 eV, and 288.2 eV can be indexed to C–C/C = C, C–S, C–N, C–O, and C = O bond, respectively. The presence of O-related peaks is ascribed to the surface oxidation of the sample in air. In general, doping with an appropriate heteroatom such as N, S, and B can adjust the physical and electronic properties of carbon efficiently, which results in an increase in the interaction between the carbon structure and the adsorbed oxygen molecules [61,62]. Therefore, the N, S co-doping strategy can endow more active sites and an efficient electron transport rate, which are considered favorable for enhancing the ORR performance. The inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis of Zn-Co-S@NSC, Zn-S@NSC, and Co-S@NSC were conducted to confirm the exact ratio of chemical elements. The ICP-OES results (Table S3) further shows that atomic ratio of Zn/Co/S is 0.48:0.13:1, which is in a good agreement with the XPS results. In addition, the results of CHNOS elemental analysis show that the atomic percentage of S element increases from 0 to 15.24% after pyrolysis (Table S4), further indicating the successful formation of Zn-Co-S@NSC 3.2 Electrochemical measurement of the prepared samples To evaluate the electrochemical performance of the as-prepared Zn-Co-S@NSC, cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement was first performed at a sweep rate of 100 mV s−1 in an N2- (dashed line) and O2-saturated (solid line) 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution. In the CV curves in Fig. 4 a, no noticeable peak is observed for any of the samples in the N2-saturated solution, which is derived from the typical electrical double layer capacitance of the catalysts. The rectangular-like area of the Zn-Co-S@NSC is larger than those of all the samples owing to its higher surface area and surface roughness, which is associated with more accessible electrocatalytic active sites. Distinct ORR peaks were detected in the O2-saturated electrolyte at approximately 0.5–0.7 V vs. RHE. The peak voltage of the Zn-Co-S@NSC is more cathodic than those of the Zn-S@NSC and Co-S@NSC catalysts, which indicates the remarkable ORR electrocatalytic activity of Zn-Co-S@NSC (Fig. 4a). To assess the ORR performance of these samples further, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were obtained on an RDE in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm. As shown in Fig. 4b, the Zn-Co-S@NSC catalyst displays remarkably higher onset-potential (0.955 V vs. RHE), which is more positive than those of Zn-S@NSC (0.867 V) and Co-S@NSC (0.940 V). It is also comparable to that of commercial Pt/C (0.907 V). Moreover, Zn-Co-S@NSC possesses a higher limiting current density (−5.92 mA cm−2) at 0.4 V vs. RHE than those of Zn-S@NSC (−3.86 mA cm−2) and Co-S@NSC (−4.81 mA cm−2), which is even comparable to that of Pt/C (−5.90 mA cm−2). Compared with the benchmark Pt/C or recently reported transition metal‐based electrocatalysts, our Zn-Co-S@NSC catalyst exhibits highly attractive electrocatalytic activity for ORR in alkaline conditions (Table S5). The involved electron transfer number (n) at different potentials for the sample is calculated using the Koutecky–Levich (K–L) equation. As shown in Fig. 4c, LSV curves of the samples are obtained at various rotating speeds (400–2025 rpm). The inset of Fig. 4c shows K–L plots for Zn-Co-S@NSC with good linear correlation between J−1 and ω−1/2 for the potential range 0.3–4.5 V vs. RHE, indicating first-order reaction kinetics toward the concentration of dissolved oxygen. As shown in Fig. 4c, the average value of n of Zn-Co-S@NSC is determined to be 3.96. This is considerably higher than those of Zn-S@NSC (2.35) and Co-S@NSC (3.37) (Fig. S9), indicating that the ORR over this catalyst is dominated by a desirable four-electron process. The significantly improved catalytic activity of Zn-Co-S@NSC was also assessed from the mass-transport corrected Tafel slopes, as shown in Fig. 4d. The slopes of the Tafel plot in the low-overpotential region were investigated to analyze the kinetic mechanism of the prepared catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 4d, a much smaller Tafel slope of 42 mV dec−1 was observed for Zn-Co-S@NSC compared to 64 and 65.6 mV dec−1 for Zn-S@NSC and Co-S@NSC, which is even lower than 57.5 mV dec−1 for state-of-the-art Pt/C. Zn-Co-S@NSC also shows an impressive kinetic current density of −29.97 mA cm−2 at 0.8 V vs. RHE, which is even superior to those of Zn-S@NSC (−0.15 mA cm−2) and Co-S@NSC (−8.14 mA cm−2) (Fig. S10). To further examine the kinetics of the as-obtained samples, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement for the prepared samples were conducted at a constant potential of 0.8 V vs. RHE between 100 mHz and 100 kHz (Fig. S11). In the Nyquist plot obtained from the EIS measurement, the diameter of semicircle represents the charge transfer resistance (Rct), which is a vital factor for assessing electrocatalytic activity for ORR. The Zn-Co-S@NSC exhibits the smallest Rct value (71.0 Ω) compared with those of Zn-S@NSC (102.3 Ω) and Co-S@NSC (470.9 Ω), which can be ascribed to the synergistic effects of bimetallic sulfide. The long-term electrochemical stability and remarkable methanol tolerance of ORR electrocatalysts are also important for the commercialization of fuel cell devices. The stability of the Zn-Co-S@NSC micro-polyhedra and commercial Pt/C catalyst is first investigated based on chronoamperometric responses at 0.6 V vs. RHE in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm (Fig. 4e). The current density for the Zn-Co-S@NSC was retained well (~99.7%) after continuous operation for 100 h, indicating the remarkable long-term durability of the Zn-Co-S@NSC. Meanwhile, a significant current decay of 30.5% was observed for the commercial Pt/C catalyst. The current density of the commercial Pt/C decreases instantly with the introduction of methanol into the O2-saturated electrolyte. Meanwhile, the Zn-Co-S@NSC is much less vulnerable to methanol injection (Fig. 4f), signifying the strong tolerance of the Zn-Co-S@NSC to methanol crossover. 3.3 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations To elucidate the origin of the remarkable ORR performance of the Zn-Co-S@NSC catalyst, we further conducted density functional theory (DFT) calculations to investigate the synergistic effect of binary metal systems on electrochemical activity for ORR. The computational calculations were performed through four-electron transfer steps in an alkaline solution [43]: (4) O2(g) + 2H2O(l) + 4e– + * → *OOH + OH– + H2O(l) + 3e– (5) *OOH + OH– + H2O(l) + 3e– → *O + 2OH– + H2O(l) + 2e– (6) *O + 2OH– + H2O(l) + 2e– → *OH + 3OH– + e– (7) *OH + 3OH– + e– → 4OH– + * where “*” denotes a surface empty adsorption site of catalyst. *O, *OH, and *OOH indicate adsorbed species on the surface site. In general, the step with the largest ΔGi is regarded as the potential‐determining step (PDS) for ORR [63]. According to the Gibbs free energy diagram at an equilibrium potential of 0.402 V (Fig. 5 ), the first process (OOH* formation) is recognized as the PDS of the ORR for the Zn–S catalyst, while for the Zn–Co–S catalyst the last *OH + 3OH– + e– → 4OH– + * reaction is considered to be the PDS. This indicates the significantly facilitated dissociation of O2 on the Zn-Co-S catalysts compared to the Zn–S case, which results in the enhanced ORR performance. As a result, the overpotentials (η) for the Zn–Co–S catalysts (η = 0.533 V (CoZnS-terminated) and 0.494 V (ZnS-terminated)) are strikingly reduced compared to the Zn–S case (η = 0.794 V). The above theoretical calculations demonstrate that the addition of Co into ZnS could significantly improve the ORR catalysis by optimizing the affinity of catalyst surface with oxygen species. The above results demonstrate that Zn-Co-S@NSC exhibits a remarkable ORR activity compared to its unary sulfide counterparts. In addition, the ORR activity is comparable to that of commercial Pt/C. This superior electrochemical performance of Zn-Co-S@NSC could be ascribed to the following factors: (1) Owing to the synergistic effects of binary metallic species, the synthesized metal sulfides exhibit an optimized electronic structure compared with the single metal sulfides, and this helps in improving the electronic conductivity [64,65]. (2) The 3D hierarchical porous architecture is effective for reducing the O2 diffusion length during electrochemical reactions and facilitating charge transportation along various directions. The porous structure exposes and offers more electrochemical active sites, which is advantageous for enhancing ORR activities. Also, the as-prepared Zn-Co-S@NSC exhibits a relatively large surface area with high porosity, providing abundant adjacent active sites for electrochemical catalysis. (3) As revealed by the elemental mapping using EDS (Fig. 1e), the homogeneous dispersion of Zn0.76Co0.24S nanoparticles on N and S co-doped carbon effectively maximizes the number of active sites and conductivity for electrochemical oxygen reduction. (4) The theoretical calculations further demonstrated that the Zn-Co-S@NSC exhibits a smaller Gibbs free energy variation for adsorbed intermediates of the ORR, compared with that of unary metal sulfide, which is well consistent with experimental results. Overall, the outstanding electrocatalytic activity, long-term stability, and methanol tolerance of Zn-Co-S@NSC make it a promising highly efficient and durable electrocatalyst for ORR. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully synthesized bi-metallic zinc cobalt sulfides uniformly dispersed on N, S co-doped carbon (Zn-Co-S@NSC) as a highly efficient electrocatalyst for ORR through a simple simultaneous sulfurization and carbonization of Zn-Co-ZIF under Ar atmosphere. The experimental results and a theoretical investigation indicated that the unique porous architecture and synergistic interactions between binary metallic species and N and S co-doped carbon play a vital role in the improvement of the electrocatalytic performance on ORR. The prepared Zn-Co-S@NSC electrocatalyst displayed remarkable ORR activity in an alkaline solution (−5.92 mA cm−2 at 0.4 V vs. RHE), long-term durability (over 100 h), and methanol tolerance ability. Consequently, this study provides a new method for obtaining binary metallic sulfides on carbon and the method can be applied to electrocatalysts for energy storage and conversion technologies. coredata.dc:description: Herein, pyrolysis strategy assisted by a dual-metal-ZIF is developed to synthesize porous zinc cobalt sulfide supported on nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon (Zn-Co-S@NSC). A dodecahedral ZIF architecture is first constructed with two metal sources, followed by a pyrolysis process with thiourea to obtain hollow composite materials consisting of Zn-Co sulfide uniformly dispersed on nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon. Benefitting from the distinctive structure and synergistic effect of the binary metal system, the as-prepared Zn-Co-S@NSC displays excellent electrocatalytic performance on ORR in alkaline condition. The superior performances, which are evaluated in terms of onset-potential (0.955 V vs. RHE) and half-wave potential (0.831 V vs. RHE), are comparable to the conventional Pt/C catalyst. In addition, Zn-Co-S@NSC exhibits remarkable electrochemical durability and exceptional methanol tolerance compared to the commercial Pt/C. The DFT calculations further demonstrate that the binary metal system can promote electrocatalytic activity by optimizing the reaction free energy for intermediates of ORR.
coredata.dc:title: Hollow hierarchical zinc cobalt sulfides derived from bimetallic-organic-framework as a non-precious electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction reaction
